questions.text: A woman with cervical cancer is posted to undergo the procedure shown in the image below. Which of the following is true about the procedure?

choices.text: Not useful if the transformation zone cannot be completely visualized
Suitable only for lesions of ectocervix without endocervical involvement
Has no bearing on the future pregnancies
Can be both diagnostic and therapeutic

questions.solution:
The given procedure is conization, which can be both diagnostic and therapeutic for cancer cervix.

Conization is a gynecological procedure performed in an operation theatre under anesthesia, where the entire outer margin of the cervix and endocervical lining short of the internal os is removed.

Indications for the procedure are : 

  • When the transformation zone is not completely visualized (option A)
  • Endocervical dysplasia (option B)
  • When there is a discrepancy in findings between cytology, colposcopy and biopsy
  • When micro invasion is suspected

Since it provides tissue for histopathological study in suspected cases of cancer cervix, it is diagnostic. It is also considered therapeutic in Stage IA1 cervical cancer.

Complications of the procedure include bleeding, sepsis, cervical stenosis, abortion and preterm labor (option C).

questions.text: A 48-year-old premenopausal woman presents to the OPD for her annual check-up. She has no history of diabetes or tamoxifen use. A pelvic ultrasound was performed, which revealed a 9mm hyperechoic focal mass within the endometrial cavity. Doppler USG was performed, and the image is given below. What is the management of her condition?
questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario, doppler USG showing a feeding vessel is characteristic of an endometrial polyp. Polyps less than 10mm, which are incidentally detected in asymptomatic women, are followed up as they will spontaneously resolve or slough.

Polyp size (>1.5 cm), postmenopausal women, age>60 years, tamoxifen use, diabetes, and obesity are associated with increased risk of malignant transformation. In such cases, operative hysteroscopic polypectomy may be most effective. Oral contraceptive pills appear to be protective. For women taking tamoxifen, the levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNG-IUS) was investigated and shown to lower endometrial polyp formation rates.

Benign endometrial polyps

Women with polyps may present with heavy cyclic or intermenstrual bleeding or without complaints as an incidental finding on imaging. Estrogen and progesterone have been implicated in the growth of endometrial polyps, and higher receptor levels are seen compared with the normal endometrium.

On transvaginal sonography, endometrial polyps may appear as nonspecific areas of endometrial thickening or a round or elongated hyperechoic focal mass within the endometrial cavity. Some polyps may contain cystic spaces corresponding to dilated endometrial glands.  On color or power Doppler, endometrial polyps typically have only one arterial feeding vessel.

Treatment:

- Asymptomatic polyps usually don't need any intervention

- Symptomatic:

  • Removal with ring forceps (Option C): The polyp is twisted repeatedly about the base of its stalk to strangulate its feeding vessels. With repeated twisting, the base narrows and avulses.
  • Removal with punch biopsy forceps for smaller polyps. (Option D)
  • Electrosurgical excision or hysteroscopic removal for polyps with thick stalks. (Option A)

After the removal of polyps, the base can be cauterized to prevent bleeding and recurrence rate. Every excised polyp should be sent for further histological examination to rule out malignancy.

questions.text: A 46-year-old multiparous woman presented with menorrhagia accompanied by dysmenorrhea. On examination, the uterus was symmetrically enlarged and tender. The transvaginal USG findings are given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of menorrhagia with accompanying dysmenorrhoea and the transvaginal ultrasound(TVS) showing the Venetian blind appearance is suggestive of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis refers to the growth of the endometrium (both stromal and glandular components) directly into the myometrium. It is predominantly seen in multiparous women above the age of 40 years. Patients generally present with menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea, and sometimes dyspareunia. On examination, there is a gross symmetrical enlargement of the uterus corresponding to 12-14 weeks size. The uterus is soft and tender on bimanual examination.

TVS findings include alternating vertical stripes of hyperechoic and hypoechoic bands, which is called the Venetian blind appearance. MRI can also be done for diagnosis. However, the only definitive mode of diagnosis is histopathological examination.

Since most women affected by the condition are past the childbearing age, total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localized excision/Levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried in younger women.

Other options: 

Option A: Leiomyoma clinically presents similarly to adenomyosis, but the size of the enlarged uterus can go up to 20 weeks gestation, and the contour is usually irregular.

Option C: Endometrial polyps are overgrowths of benign endometrial stroma covered by mucinous columnar epithelium. They appear as smooth polypoid masses arising from the endometrium into the uterine cavity. USG below shows a characteristic feeding vessel sign on the color Doppler.

Option D: Endometriosis is the presence of endometrium at a site outside the uterine cavity. It can be found in ectopic sites such as the ovary, pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligaments, appendix, pelvic lymph nodes, lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) scar endometriosis, umbilicus, and lung.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with excessive bleeding during menstruation, accompanied by a feeling of heaviness in her lower abdomen. Her periods last for 8-10 days and are associated with the passage of clots. An ultrasound of her pelvis reveals a well-defined, heterogeneous hypoechoic mass. Which among the following drugs are not helpful in the shrinkage of this tumour before surgery?
questions.solution:
The clinical case and ultrasound findings point to a diagnosis of uterine fibroid (leiomyoma), and misoprostol does not help shrink the size or reduce the vascularity of the tumor. 

Drugs to reduce the size of the fibroid:

  • Antiprogesterone – Mifepristone/RU-486.
  • Danazol (usually not used due to androgenic side effects).
  • GnRH 
    • Agonists – goserelin, leuprolide, triptorelin, nafarelin.
    • Antagonists – cetrorelix, ganirelix.
  • Selective progesterone receptor modulator (SPRMs) – Ulipristal, Asoprisnil.

Other medical methods used in the treatment of fibroids:

  • Levonorgestrel intrauterine device - controls bleeding effectively.
  • Combined oral contraceptives
  • Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA).
  • Tranexamic acid.
  • Iron therapy for anemia.
  • Selective estrogen-receptor modulators (SERMs) like tibolone and raloxifene are used as add-back therapy along with GnRH treatment. They reduce associated vasomotor symptoms and bone loss without interfering with the size of the fibroid. 

Radiological interventions for fibroids:

  • Uterine artery embolization - Angiographic procedure where polyvinyl alcohol microspheres are introduced into both uterine arteries, producing ischemia and necrosis of the fibroid.
  • Magnetic resonance-guided focused ultrasound - Ultrasound energy is focused to cause coagulative necrosis in selected fibroids.

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.
  • Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size
  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

Related Pearl: Contraindications to uterine artery embolization

Absolute contraindications:

  • GnRH agonist use
  • Asymptomatic fibroids
  • Pregnancy
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Uterine malignancy
  • Calcified fibroid

Relative contraindications:

  • Patient desirous of future pregnancy: UAE causes poor uterine perfusion and pelvic adhesions, decreasing fertility. 
  • Postmenopausal women: Fibroids regress naturally, after menopause. Fibroid enlargement post-menopause raises the suspicion of malignancy.
  • Subserosal or submucosal fibroids: Pedunculated subtypes may detach intraperitoneally or within the uterine cavity. This may lead to sterile peritonitis or intrauterine infection.
  • Size or number of fibroids: Large fibroids or a greater number of fibroids can cause large amounts of necrosis following UAE. This may lead to post-op pain or infection. 
  • Contraindications to radiologic contrast agents.

Related Pearl: Uses of Misoprostol

INDICATIONS PRIMARY DOSE OF MISOPROSTOL REMARKS

MEDICAL TERMINATION OF PREGNANCY

 

Combined Regimen(recommended):
Upto 12 weeks of gestation-800mcg vaginally, buccally or sublingually.

Beyond 12 weeks of gestation-400mcg vaginally, buccally or sublingually every 3 hours


Misoprostol only regimen:
Upto 12 weeks-800mcg vaginally, buccally or sublingually

Beyond 12 weeks-400mcg vaginally, bucally or sublingually every 3 hours

Ideally used 1-2 days after 200mg of Mifepristone in the combined regimen.


The mucosal route of administration is preferred over the oral route of administration.


These doses also apply for incomplete and missed abortion.

SURGICAL ABORTION

12-14weeks- both medical and surgical methods can be done

>14weeks-surgical method 

 Cervical preparation: 400mcg vaginally/ sublingually

Another method: Oral Mifepristone 200mg 24-48 hours before the procedure

 
PPH Prophylaxis

800mcg sublingual single dose OR 600mcg orally/ sublingually/rectally

single dose for PPH secondary prevention (approx >350ml blood loss)

  Where oxytocin is not available or storage conditions are inadequate
PPH treatment 800 mcg sublingually single dose

questions.text: True for bacterial vaginosis (BV) is all except?

choices.text: Nugent's criteria aids in the diagnosis of BV
Amsel’s criteria is used for the diagnosis of BV

questions.solution:
Bacterial vaginosis is termed vaginosis is associated with alteration in the normal vaginal flora i.e. decrease in the number of lactoba­cilli in the vaginal discharge with 100-fold increase in growth of other anaerobic bacteria namely Haemophilus vaginalis, Gardnerella, Mobiluncus and Myco­plasma hominis.

  • Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is the most common cause of vaginitis.
  • Nugent's criteria is used to quantify or grade bacteria via Gram stain of vaginal samples.
    • In brief, Nugent's criteria evaluate 3 types of bacteria via Gram stain: Lactobacillus, Bacteroides/Gardnerella, and Mobiluncus.
    • They are each graded on a scale of 1-4 (1+ is < 1 cell per field, 2+ is 1-5 cells per field, 3+ is 6-30 cells per field, and 4+ is >30 cells per field).
    • In this system, Lactobacillus and Bacteroides/Gardnerella are given scores between 0-4 but Mobiluncus is only graded from 0-2.
    • Total scores are then calculated and used as follows: 0-3 (Normal), 4-6 (intermediate bacterial count), and 7-10 (bacterial vaginosis).
  • Amsel’s criteria is used for diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis which includes
    • Homogenous vaginal discharge
    • Vaginal pH > 4.5
    • Amine like odour on adding KOH (Whiff test positive)
    • Clue cells (>20% of cells)
  • Atleast 2 of the four criteria should be present to confirm diagnosis.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginitis

Candidal vaginitis
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomonas vaginalis Candida albicans
Aetiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual transmission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test The whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text:
A multiparous non-lactating obese lady seeks contraception advice. She has deranged blood glucose levels from her last pregnancy. She had an ectopic pregnancy 3 years back. Which oral contraceptive pill is best suited for her?

GDM - Gestational Diabetes Mellitus
questions.solution:
The oral contraceptive pill best suited for this patient is a triphasic combined oral contraceptive pill (OCP). It has no adverse effect on carbohydrate and lipid metabolism and has a good safety profile in diabetic women. 

Triphasic combined oral contraceptive pills are those with estrogen and progesterone dosages varying in three different phases of the same cycle. 

These are preparations of Ethinyl estradiol (EE2) and levonorgestrel (LNG) given as 3 phases in a menstrual cycle with different dosages- 

  • First 6 days- 30mcg EE2 + 50mcg LNG
  • Next 5 days- 40mcg EE2 + 75mcg LNG
  • For the next 10 days- 30mcg EE2 + 125mcg LNG 
  • Followed by a 1-week drug-free interval 

These triphasic OCPs can be safely used in those at risk of myocardial infarction. These are as effective as monophasic pills but are not used in cases with menorrhagia.

During contraceptive use, if one dose is missed, that day’s pill plus the missed pill should be taken as soon as remembered and the remaining pack is then completed as usual. If several doses are missed, then two pills are taken with an additional effective barrier technique for the next 7 days or a new pack can be started with an additional barrier method.

Other options:

Progesterone-only pills /mini-pills can be given for diabetes, but the failure rate is higher in obese women. There is a high risk of ectopic pregnancy (up to 10% of pregnancies reported in clinical studies) in progestin-only oral contraceptive users. Since this woman already has a history of ectopic, this may not be a preferable method. 

Monophasic pills comprise a constant dose of progestin and estrogen throughout the cycle. It causes derangement of lipid and carbohydrate metabolism and thus is contraindicated in diabetes mellitus. 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

Related Pearl: Types of monophasic combined oral pills

Type Estrogen Progestogen
1st Generation Ethinyl oestradiol Norethindrone
2nd Generation Ethinyl oestradiol Norgestrel, LNG
3rd Generation Ethinyl oestradiol Desogestrel,gestodene norgestimate
4th Generation
(Yasmin)		 Ethinyl oestradiol Drospirenone

questions.text: A young man has recently undergone a vasectomy. To declare him as sterile, what is the ideal follow-up test advised?

choices.text: Two semen analyses done at 12 and 16 weeks demonstrating absent spermatazoa
One semen analysis done at 6 weeks demonstrating absent spermatazoa
One semen analysis done at 28 weeks demonstrating absent spermatozoa
Two semen analyses done at 12 and 36 months demonstrating absent spermatazoa

questions.solution:
Two consecutive semen analyses are done at 12 and 16 weeks demonstrating absent spermatozoa before the patient is declared sterile.

Vasectomy is a permanent sterilisation procedure done in males, where a segment of the vas deferens is resected and ligated bilaterally. The patient would have to use additional contraceptive measures for 3 months.

It is a relatively simple procedure with low rates of complications. A patient who had a vasectomy is not sterile immediately after the procedure as semen is stored in distal channels of the vas deferens for varying periods. Hence, for this reason, it is estimated that at least 20 ejaculations are required to empty the stored semen. The patient is then examined either by one test after 16 weeks or by two tests at 12 and 16 weeks, and if these two consecutive semen analyses show the absence of spermatozoa then the patient can be declared sterile. Until then, additional contraceptives (condoms or DMPA for the wife) should be recommended.

questions.text: You suspect genital infection in a patient with complaints of infertility after the hysterosalpingography showed the following finding. You plan to do an endometrial biopsy to confirm the diagnosis. When is the right time to do the biopsy if she has a regular 28-day menstrual cycle?
questions.solution:
The given hysterosalpingography image shows the typical "tobacco pouch" appearance of the fallopian tube, which is highly suggestive of tuberculous salpingitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Endometrial biopsy is done on day 26 of the cycle as the tubercle bacilli are present in the deeper layers of the endometrium and come to the surface just before menstruation. Hence, an endometrial biopsy is done 1 or 2 days before menstruation.

Genital tuberculosis: The leading presenting complaints include infertility, abdominal pain, vaginal discharge, and suspicion of neoplasm. 10-15% of women are found to be asymptomatic as well. It mostly spreads via the haematogenous route. Lymphatic spread is also seen sometimes. It can rarely spread by direct contact with the affected intraabdominal organs or peritoneum. 

The fallopian tubes are the most common site to be affected. The disease subsequently spreads to other genital organs and the peritoneum. The endometrium is involved in 60% of cases. The infection is from the tubes either by lymphatics or by direct spread through continuity. Cornual ends are commonly affected due to their dual blood supply, as well as their anatomical proximity to tubes. 

Investigations:

1. Complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), enzyme-linked immunoabsorbent assay (ELISA) tests - lgG and IgM, and Mantoux tests are done to evaluate the case of genital tuberculosis. The nucleic acid amplification technique (NAAT) can detect tuberculosis within a few hours compared to culture.

2. Hysterosalpingography- If genital tuberculosis is suspected, it should not be performed because of the risk of spread of infection.

If performed in an asymptomatic woman, the following patterns may be seen:

  • Tobacco-pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx with blocked fimbrial end
  • Rigid non-peristaltic pipe-like tube (lead-pipe appearance)
  • Beading and variation in filling defect
  • The jagged fluffiness of the tubal outline
  • Golf club appearance with slight or moderate dilatation of the ampullary portion of the fallopian tube

3. The investigation of choice in genital tuberculosis is an endometrial biopsy. Endometrium tissue is obtained by D&C/hystroscopy-directed biopsy. The endometrial scrapings are used for histopathology, PCR testing, and AFB smear and culture. 

4. Laparoscopy: Diagnostic laparoscopy is widely used to establish the diagnosis of genital tuberculosis/ abdominal pelvic tuberculosis. Tuberculous lesions can be seen on the parietal peritoneum, intestinal serosa, omentum, surface of the uterus, and fallopian tubes.

The image below shows the "pipe stem" or "lead pipe" appearance. There is an absence of normal tortuosity and a curved or straight pipe-like appearance shows the fibrotic stage of tuberculous salpingitis. 

The image below shows multiple constrictions along the fallopian tube, giving rise to a "beaded" appearance.

Image below shows sacculation of both tubes in distal portion with an associated hydrosalpinx giving a Golf club-like appearance.

Image below shows " Tobacco pouch" appearance of the fallopian tube.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below.
questions.solution:
The shown forceps have no catch and have fenestrated blades suggestive of ovum forceps.

Ovum forceps are used to remove the products of conception in dilation and evacuation without crushing the conceptus. Other uses are:

  • Removal of molar tissue from hydatidiform mole
  • Removal of small uterine polyp

Uterine wall injuries are minimal due to the absence of a catch. It is introduced with the blades closed and then opened inside the uterine cavity to grasp the products. The instrument is taken out with a slight rotatory movement. The rotatory movement facilitates the detachment of the products from the uterine wall and minimizes the injury of the uterine wall if accidentally grasped.

The following image shows the ovum forceps. 

Other options:

Option A- Sponge holding forceps are used to:

  • Clean skin with a swab dipped in antiseptic solution during any abdominal or vaginal operations
  • Toilet vulva, vagina, and perineum before and following delivery
  • Hold the membranes if it threatens to tear during delivery of the placenta
  • Hold the cervix during cerclage procedures

The following image shows the sponge holding forceps. 

Option C- Lane's tissue forceps are used to:

  • Hold parietal wall for retraction during abdominal operations with transverse incision (hysterectomy)
  • Hold the polyp or fibroid in polypectomy or myomectomy surgery
  • Hold towel during draping

The following image shows Lane's tissue forceps. 

Option D- Allis tissue forceps are used to:

  • Catch the anterior lip of the cervix in a dilation and evacuation procedure
  • Hold the apex of the episiotomy wound during repair
  • Catch hold margins of the peritoneum, rectus sheath, and vaginal mucosa during repair
  • Catch hold the torn ends of the external sphincter ani before suture repair of complete perineal tear

The following image shows Allis tissue forceps. 

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: A 23-year-old in the postnatal period after her first delivery developed a uterine prolapse of the level given below. What would be the most appropriate management in her case?
questions.solution:
Ring pessaries are the preferred management in the case of prolapse in the postnatal period.

Uterine prolapses following delivery should be managed conservatively for 3-4 months, with abdominal exercises, massage, and perineal exercises.  Young women rapidly improve if appropriate conservative methods are employed. If surgery is performed within 6 months of delivery, there is a high chance of recurrence of the prolapse.

The image below shows the various degrees of uterovaginal prolapse.

Various surgeries were performed for the management of uterovaginal prolapse:

  1. Anterior colporrhaphy: This is done for cystocele or cystourethrocele.
  2. Posterior colporrhaphy/ colpoperineorrhaphy: This is done for posterior defects like rectocele or rectal defects with perineal laxity.
  3. Le Forte's repair: This is preferred only in elderly women with advanced prolapse, or those unfit for surgery. Women wanting an active sexual life are poor candidates for this procedure as it creates an adhesive area in the midline.
  4. Abdominal sling surgeries: Young women desirous of retaining menstrual and reproductive functions are ideal candidates. These surgeries use tapes as slings to prevent organ descent. These include:
    1. Abdominal wall cervicopexy (modified by Purandare and Mathre) - sling attached to cervix posteriorly near uterosacral ligaments. 
    2. Shirodkar's sling surgery - the sling fixes the cervix to the lumbosacral fascia.
    3. Khanna's sling surgery - sling fixed to the anterior superior iliac spine, strengthening the Mackenrodt's ligament. 
  5. Fothergill surgery (Manchester operation): An anterior colporrhaphy is combined with amputation of the cervix. The Mackenrodt ligaments are then sutured in front of the cervix followed by a colpoperineorrhaphy. It is suitable for women <40 years desiring reproductive function, but fertility may be reduced.
  6. Ward-Mayo surgery: This is a combination of vaginal hysterectomy + pelvic floor repair. It is done in women >40 years, not desiring reproductive function.
  7. Moschowitz surgery: This is performed for enterocele repair where the pouch of Douglas is obliterated.

questions.text:
Match the following.
Section A Section B
1. Granulosa cell tumor a. Schiller-Duval bodies
2. Endodermal sinus tumor b. Walthard cell nest
3. Brenner tumor c. Hobnail cell
4. Clear cell tumor d. Call–Exner bodies
questions.solution:
The correctly matched ovarian tumors with their pathological findings include:

Tumor type HPE finding
Granulosa cell tumor Call–Exner bodies
Endodermal sinus tumor Schiller-Duval bodies
Brenner tumor Walthard cell nest 
Clear cell tumor Hobnail cell

The images below show Call-Exner bodies, a pathognomic of granulosa cell tumor. Call-Exner bodies are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material similar to immature follicles. Granulosa cells with pale, grooved, “coffee bean” nuclei are seen. 

The image below shows the Schiller-Duval body, which is pathognomic of the endodermal sinus tumor. Schiller-Duval bodies are seen in yolk sac tumors and appear as glomerulus-like structures with a central blood vessel enveloped by tumor cells in a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

The image below shows Walthard cell rests and coffee bean nuclei, which are pathognomic of Brenner's tumor. Walthard cell rests are benign clusters of epithelial cells resembling transitional cells.

The image below shows the hobnail cell, which is pathognomic of clear cell ovarian tumors. They are clear cells showing large dark nuclei protruding into the lumen. 

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

questions.text:
A young woman is suspected to have pelvic inflammatory disease. Which of her given findings are considered the minimum criteria for clinically diagnosing pelvic inflammatory disease?
  1. Lower abdominal tenderness
  2. Raised ESR or CRP
  3. Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with Chlamydia trachomatis.
  4. Cervical motion tenderness
  5. Mucopurulent cervical discharge
questions.solution:
The minimum criteria for clinical diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) include:

  • Lower abdominal tenderness (Statement 1)
  • Adnexal tenderness
  • Cervical motion tenderness (Statement 4)

Additional criteria for diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) are:

  • Oral temperature >38.3oC
  • Mucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge and cervical friability (Statement 5)
  • Presence of abundant WBC on saline microscopy of vaginal fluid
  • Raised ESR or CRP (Statement 2)
  • Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with N. gonorrhoea or C. trachomatis (Statement 3).

Any one of the minimum criteria + 1 or more additional criteria are required for the clinical diagnosis of PID.

The definitive diagnosis of PID is through,

  • Histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsy
  • Imaging study (TVS/MRI) evidence showing evidence of thickened fluid-filled tubes indicating tubo-ovarian abscess.
  • Laparoscopic evidence of PID

Outpatient management of PID: Inj. ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose + doxycycline 100 mg BD x 14 days + metronidazole 500 mg BD x 14 days.

Indications for hospitalization in PID 

  • Surgical emergencies like appendicitis, generalized peritonitis, etc. 
  • Tubo-ovarian abscess
  • Pregnancy
  • oral temperature >38.5°C, severe nausea and vomiting
  • Unable to follow or tolerate an outpatient oral regimen
  • No clinical response to oral antimicrobial therapy

Parenteral treatment for PID in hospitalized patients: 

  • Inj. cefotetan + oral doxycycline 
  • (or) Inj. cefoxitin + oral doxycycline
  • (or) Inj.clindamycin + inj. gentamicin 

After clinical improvement of the patient with parenteral therapy, transition to oral therapy with doxycycline and metronidazole is recommended to complete 14 days of antimicrobial therapy.

To minimize disease transmission, women should be instructed to abstain from sexual intercourse until therapy is completed, symptoms have resolved, and partners have been adequately treated.

questions.text: A 32-year-old P2L2 lady with a history of uterine fibroids with distortion of the uterine cavity comes to the clinic. She had unprotected intercourse 4 days back and does not want to get pregnant. What will be your advice for contraception for this lady?
questions.solution:
Ulipristal acetate 30 mg single dose should be advised for emergency contraception for this patient as it can be taken up to 5 days after unprotected sexual intercourse.

Ulipristal is a synthetic progesterone receptor modulator. It attaches to the progesterone receptor and acts by:

  • Preventing/delaying ovulation
  • Suppressing endometrial and follicular growth
  • Inhibiting implantation

Side effects are headaches and mood changes. It is contraindicated in women with severe hepatic dysfunction and severe asthma.

Other options:

Option A: Levonorgestrel (LNG) 1.5 mg, i.e. 2 tablets of LNG 0.75 mg, can be used as a single-dose emergency contraceptive. This should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. Alternatively, one tablet of LNG 0.75 mg can be followed by another tablet 12 hours later. 

Option B: Centchroman is effective only if taken within 24 hours of unprotected sexual intercourse. A 60 mg tablet taken twice in 24 hours can be effective in preventing implantation.

Option C: CuT is a non-hormonal method of contraception. It can be inserted up to 5 days after unprotected sexual intercourse. It is not used in this case as the patient has a past history of fibroids and a distorted uterine cavity.

Contraindications for copper-IUD:

  • Uterine abnormality with the distorted uterine cavity
  • Acute PID or current behavior suggesting a high risk for PID
  • Postpartum endometritis or postabortal endometritis in the past 3 months
  • Known or suspected uterine or cervical malignancy
  • Genital bleeding of unknown etiology
  • Mucopurulent cervicitis
  • Wilson disease
  • Allergy to copper
  • A previously placed IUD that has not been removed

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables

    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with increased lower abdominal pain on the first two days of her menses, which subsides on the third day. There is no excessive bleeding. She started menstruating one year back. She has no other complaints, and her examination findings are normal. What is her condition best described as?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of lower abdominal pain with no associated symptoms or underlying cause is most likely to be primary dysmenorrhea. Onset within 2 years of menarche and symptoms during the beginning of menstruation further support the diagnosis.

Dysmenorrhea is defined as cramping pain accompanying menstruation.

Classification of dysmenorrhea:

A. Etiological:

  • Primary dysmenorrhea affects more than half of post-pubescent women in the age group of 18 to 25 years, with ovulatory cycles. It does not have any particular cause. 
  • Secondary (acquired) dysmenorrhea is associated with the presence of organic pelvic pathologies such as fibroids, adenomyosis, PID, and endometriosis.
    Unilateral dysmenorrhea can be seen in a rudimentary horn of the bicornuate uterus, IUCD users, and cervical stenosis.

B.  Clinical:

  • Spasmodic dysmenorrhea is the most prevalent type, characterized by cramping pain before or at the start of menstruation, especially on the first and second days of menstruation.
  • Congestive dysmenorrhea is seen in PID, IUCD users, pelvic vein varicosities, pelvic endometriosis, and fibroids. These patients have increasing pelvic discomfort and pelvic pain a few days before menstruation, after which they have rapid relief of the symptoms. 
  • Membranous dysmenorrhea is characterized by endometrial shedding as a cast during menses, and this passage of the cast leads to painful uterine cramps. It is the rarest variety.

questions.text: You are assisting in a tubal sterilization procedure where the senior resident performs the following technique. This procedure is known as:
questions.solution:
The sterilization procedure shown in the above image is Irving's procedure. It involves ligating and excising the mid-portion of the tube after which the proximal stump is buried into the myometrium. The distal stump is buried in the broad ligament.

It is often done in conjunction with caesarian sections. It is a reliable method of sterilization, but not a reversible technique and may require a laparotomy incision.

Other methods of sterilization include:

1. Laparotomy/Minilaparotomy:

  • Pomeroy's procedure: The fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision, and the middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut and excised. It is surgically reversible.
  • Madlener's procedure: A loop of the fallopian tube is crushed and then ligated with a nonabsorbable suture.
  • Kroener's technique: It refers to fimbriectomy done by ligating the distal ampulla of the tube with two permanent sutures followed by division and removal of the infundibulum. It is irreversible.
  • Uchida's method: The serosa in the midsegment of the tube is stripped off from the mucosa and then excised. The proximal segment is ligated and buried in the broad ligament. The minimum tubal excision preserves the potential for tuboplasty.
  • Cornual resection: The cornual part of the tube is resected between two clamps.

2. Laparoscopic techniques: Each fallopian tube is picked up near the isthmic end (2–3 cm away) and clipped or banded with silastic bands, Filshie clips, Hulka band, or falope silastic rings. It is a reversible technique.

3. Hysteroscopic sterilization with the Essure permanent device: It is made of a flexible stainless steel inner coil and a nickel-titanium outer coil (nitinol). Polyethylene terephthalate (PET) in the inner coil causes a benign local fibrous tissue growth that occludes the fallopian tube. It takes 3 months to occlude the tube, confirmed with hysterosalpingography. During this period of 3 months, other methods of contraception should be used. It is an irreversible technique.

questions.text: A lady with an abdominal mass was investigated. On surgery, she was found to have bilateral ovarian masses with a smooth surface. Microscopy revealed mucin-secreting cells with signet ring shapes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is suggestive of Kruckenberg tumor.

Krukenberg tumors are secondary growth in the ovary and most often arise from primary carcinoma of the stomach (70%), large bowel (15%), and breast (6%).

Features:

  • Usually bilateral
  • Have a smooth surface
  • They retain the shape of the normal ovary.
  • There is no tendency to form adhesions with neighboring viscera and they are freely movable in the pelvis.
  • There is no infiltration through the capsule
  • Have a waxy consistency

Histologically, numerous signet-ring cells with pale cytoplasm are seen.

Other options:

Dysgerminona is a type of germ cell tumor and it corresponds to the seminoma of the testis. It typically manifests in young girls or in children. It is typically unilateral, and like all solid tumors, it may be linked to ascites. It secretes placental alkaline phosphatase (ALP), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and β-hCG. 

The image below shows the histopathology of a dysgerminoma. Cells are organized in clusters or alveoli that make up the tumor. The tumor cells are always accompanied by lymphocytes and large cells. 

Endodermal sinus tumor/Yolk sac tumor is a type of ovarian germ cell tumor that is seen in young girls between the age of 15 and 25 years. It is mostly unilateral. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is commonly produced by this tumor and is used as a tumor marker. 

Grossly these tumors appear as a yellow, friable (hemorrhagic), solid mass. Microscopically, these tumors show Schiller-Duval bodies, which are seen as papillary projections composed of a central core of blood vessels and are lined by tumor cells. They are pathognomonic when present.

Mucinous cystadenoma is a mucin-containing epithelial ovarian tumor. These tumors are usually multilocular and are lined by epithelium that resembles an endocervix They are usually unilateral and are associated with a dermoid cyst or a Brenner tumor. Grossly they have a glistening surface, and the cut section reveals multiple loculi filled with mucinous contents. If the tumor ruptures, it may lead to the formation of pseudomyxoma peritonei.

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman with a history of abortion 3 years back presents with secondary amenorrhea and a desire for pregnancy. Her hysterosalpingography revealed multiple filling defects. Her hysteroscopy is shown below. Which of the following statements regarding her condition is false?

D&C- Dilatation and curettage

choices.text: It occurs due to endometrial damage
Risk of this condition is least when D&C is done for postpartum hemorrhage
It can cause recurrent abortions due to inadequate placentation

questions.solution:
The given clinical features and hysteroscopy is suggestive of Asherman syndrome and the risk of developing Asherman syndrome is high if dilatation and curettage (D&C) are done in the postpartum period.

Asherman syndrome is a spectrum of scarring that includes filmy adhesions, dense bands, or complete obliteration of the uterine cavity. It occurs as a result of damage to the endometrium and the risk of this condition increases in pregnancy-related curettages such as incomplete abortion, postpartum hemorrhage, and elective abortion complicated by infection. Damage may also result from other uterine surgery and infection associated with an intrauterine device.

Depending on the degree of scarring, patients can develop amenorrhea (in less severe cases), hypomenorrhea, or recurrent pregnancy loss due to inadequate placentation.

Definitive diagnosis requires hysteroscopy. Treatment of Asherman syndrome is by hysteroscopic adhesiolysis. It improves fertility rates and relieves symptomatic hematometra.

questions.text:
For which of the following patients can the pills shown below be advised as a method of contraception?
  1. A 40-year-old woman with breast cancer
  2. A 25-year-old lactating mother 
  3. A 30-year-old woman who has diabetes and hypertension
  4. A 22-year-old with abnormal uterine bleeding
  5. A 35-year-old woman who is a smoker
questions.solution:
The given image is desogestrel pills (synthetic progesterone-only pills) which can be taken by lactating women, women who have diabetes and hypertension, and women who are smokers.

Progesterone-only pills are also known as minipills. They are started 21 days postpartum and soon after an abortion. The woman needs to take precautions in the first 48 hours of the first cycle.

The mechanism of action of progesterone-only pills involves thickening of the cervical mucus that inhibits penetration of sperms (mainly), atrophy of the endometrium, and inhibition of ovulation.

Advantages of progesterone-only pills include:

  • Minimal or no effects on carbohydrate and lipid metabolism
  • Do not cause or exacerbate hypertension 
  • Do not impair milk production, therefore suitable during lactation
  • Safe for women with a history of migraine headaches
  • Safe for smokers who are older than 35 years

Contraindications include abnormal uterine bleeding, breast cancer, hepatic cancer, pregnancy, and active severe liver disease. Additionally, synthetic progestogens like desogestrel are associated with a higher incidence of thromboembolism.

questions.text: A 65-year-old menopausal woman presents with vaginal bleeding. On ultrasound, her endometrial thickness was found to be  7 cms. Endometrial aspiration biopsy confirms the presence of malignant cells. Which among the following is the gold standard for staging this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of abnormal uterine bleeding in a post-menopausal woman with endometrial thickness of 7 cms and malignant cells seen on biopsy is suggestive of Endometrial carcinoma. Surgery is the gold standard for staging endometrial carcinoma.

Endometrial carcinoma is surgically staged according to the Joint 2010 International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO)/TNM classification system.

Total extra fascial hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and pelvic and para-aortic lymph node dissection is the standard staging procedure for endometrial carcinoma. 

In a menopausal woman with vaginal bleeding, even an endometrial thickness of less than 4 mm runs the risk of cancer and the entire endometrium should be subjected to histopathology study.

For those who undergo TVUS and have an EEC(endometrial echo complex) greater than 4 mm, localized thickening, or an indistinct or nonvisible EEC, endometrial sampling is a reasonable next step.

Investigations for endometrial carcinoma:

  • Endometrial aspiration biopsy
    • First investigation in abnormal uterine bleeding, especially in females >35 years.
  • Dilatation and Fractional curettage
    • It was the best method to diagnose but now it is not used.
  • Hysteroscopy and Biopsy
    • Investigation of choice for endometrial cancer.
  • Transvaginal USG
    • adjunct to endometrial biopsy.
  • Pap smear
    • Not reliable to diagnose endometrial carcinoma.
    • It is more useful as a screening tool rather than a diagnostic tool.

 If symptoms of postmenopausal bleeding persist, imaging of the endometrial cavity should be performed with one or a combination of the following: TVUS, contrast sonography, or hysteroscopy.

Note:

  • Fractional curettage is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of endometrial carcinoma whereas surgery is the gold standard investigation for staging endometrial carcinoma.
  • First investigation in Endometrial cancer: Endometrial aspiration biopsy
  • Best investigation in Endometrial cancer: Hysteroscopy and biopsy
  • Surgical staging is the gold standard investigation for staging endometrial CA

Related Pearl: Ca.Endometrium staging (Revised FIGO)

questions.text: A nursing mother was prescribed progestasert for contraception. When should you advise her to get it replaced?
questions.solution:
Progestasert would require annual replacements.

Progestasert is a T-shaped device carrying 38 mg of progesterone in a silicon oil reservoir in the vertical stem. It releases 65 μg of progesterone/day. The progesterone released causes the formation of a thick plug of mucus at the cervical os. This prevents entry of the sperms in addition to the local contraceptive effect of IUCDs.

There is lesser incidence of menstrual problems like menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea compared to copper-containing intrauterine devices. However, it is expensive and requires yearly replacement.

IUD Years of use
Progestasert 1
Cu-T-200 4
Nova T 5
LNG IUD 7-10
Cu-T-380 A 10

questions.text: A young woman is being evaluated for infertility. You decide to estimate her ovarian reserve. Which of the following can be evaluated on any day of the menstrual cycle?
questions.solution:
Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH), which is secreted by the granulosa cells, is the best marker of ovarian reserve as it can be tested on any day of the cycle.

Tests for ovarian reserve: Ovarian reserve means the capacity of the ovary to produce eggs. The other indicators include the following:

  • FSH - FSH levels are measured in the early follicular phase (Day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle) - High FSH means the ovarian reserve is getting depleted (FSH is highest in postmenopausal women). FSH (values >25 mIU/ml) levels are higher than normal in women with a reduced ovarian reserve and ovarian hypofunction. 
  • Serum estradiol values on day 3 of the cycle. Serum oestradiol >75 pg/mL indicates ovarian hypofunction.
  • LH - values <10 IU/L indicate poor reserve
  • Antral follicular count - counts less than 4–5 on days 2–5 denote poor response to hormones.
  • Inhibin B - values <40 pg/mL indicates poor reserve

Values and interpretation:

  • Normal value: 2–6.8 ng/mL
  • Poor ovarian reserve: <1 ng/mL
  • PCOD and hyperstimulation syndrome: >10 ng/mL

questions.text:
Match the following theories of endometriosis with their respective mechanisms.
1. Halban's theory a. Reflux of menstrual endometrium and subsequent implantation
2. Meyer and Ivanoff's theory b. Embolization of menstrual fragments 
3. Sampson's theory c. Metaplastic changes in embryonic mesothelium
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-b, 2-c, 3-a. 

The various theories for the etiology of endometriosis include:

Theory Mechanism
Metastatic theory by Halban Embolization of menstrual fragments through vascular and lymphatic channels
Theory of coelomic metaplasia by Meyer and Ivanoff

Metaplastic changes in embryonic mesothelium, which respond to hormone stimulation
Sampson's implantation theory Reflux of menstrual endometrium and subsequent implantation in the surrounding structures

Given below is an illustration showing retrograde menstrual flow that is leading to the development of patches of endometriosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to you with complaints of vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odor with a pH of  4.7. Microscopy reveals the cell shown in the below image. According to CDC guidelines, all the following could be used to treat this condition except?

choices.text: Metronidazole oral tablets 500 mg twice daily

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the image showing a clue cell is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis and 5% clotrimazole vaginal cream is not used in the treatment of bacterial vaginosis. 

Bacterial vaginosis is associated with alteration in the normal vaginal flora. There is a decrease in lactobacilli with a 100-fold increase in the growth of other anaerobic bacteria namely Haemophilus vaginalis, Gardnerella, Mobiluncus, and Myco­plasma hominis.

The patient complains of vaginal discharge with a fishy odor. Microscopy shows characteristic clue cells, which are vaginal epithelial cells with margins obscured by microbes. These suggest a diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis.

Amsel’s criteria are used in the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis which includes:

  • Homogenous vaginal discharge
  • Vaginal pH > 4.5
  • Amine-like odor(fishy odor) on adding KOH (Whiff test positive)
  • Clue cells (>20% of cells)

At least three of the four criteria should be present to confirm the diagnosis.

The CDC recommends one of the following treatment regimens.

  • Tablet metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days
  • Clindamycin 2% cream 5 g intravaginally for 7 days
  • Metronidazole 0.75% gel 5 g intravaginally for 5 days

Other drugs that can be used include tinidazole and secnidazole.

Sexual transmission No Yes No

Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test The whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections
