questions.text: A 40-year-old lady comes with complaints of abdominal cramping and breast pain that is cyclical and occurs once a month. It is associated with headaches and difficulty concentrating at work. She notices that the pain begins a week before menstruation and resolves after menses. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of premenstrual syndrome.

Premenstrual syndrome (premenstrual tension) is a functional disorder and is recognized by cyclical changes that are associated with ovulatory cycles. It is usually seen in middle-aged women and occurs 1-2 weeks before menstruation and resolves after menses. 

The classical symptoms include abdominal cramps, increasing breast tenderness, abdominal bloating, headache, sleeplessness, fatigue, difficulty in concentrating, and mood swings. The diagnosis is made on the basis of a carefully elicited history. Asking patients to document their symptoms in the form of a menstrual diary can also aid in diagnosis. 

Treatment includes counseling and therapy for psychological symptoms, limiting salt intake, and symptomatic treatment of breast tenderness and pelvic pain. Vitamins B1, B6, and E may be used.

Other options:

Option A: Spasmodic dysmenorrhea is the cramping pain that accompanies menstruation and is most pronounced on the first and second day of menses.

Option B: Periductal mastitis is a chronic relapsing infection of the subareolar duct of the breast. It can manifest as subareolar pain and erythema. Repeated infections can lead to scarring that causes inversion or retraction of the nipple, subareolar masses, etc. 

Option C: Endometriosis is a condition characterized by ectopic benign endometrial tissue that occurs outside the uterine cavity. Patients present with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, menorrhagia, and infertility.

questions.text: A middle-aged female presents with complaints of continuous urinary dribbling from the vagina. The methylene blue 3 swab test is done, and the middle swab is stained with blue. Cystourethroscopy reveals a fistula of size 4 cm located near the trigone of the bladder. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with constant dribbling of urine, methylene blue swab test showing staining of the middle swab, with fistula of size 4 cm located near the trigone of the bladder, is suggestive of complicated vesicovaginal fistula.

Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is a type of genital fistula, which is an abnormal communication between the genital tract and the urinary tract. It can be classified as simple or complicated. Their features are given in the table below. 

Simple VVF Complicated VVF
Size ≤ 3 cm Size > 3 cm
Located near the cuff or supra-trigonal Located away from the cuff / there is the involvement of trigone 
No prior malignancy Pelvic malignancy present
No prior radiation Prior radiation therapy
The vaginal length remains normal Vaginal length shortened
 
Vesicovaginal fistulae occur mostly due to obstetric injuries such as prolonged labour and instrumental or manipulative deliveries. Patients present with true incontinence characterised by constant dribbling of urine. The presence of urine in the undergarments is uncomfortable and leads to pruritus and excoriation of the genital area. 

Investigations to be performed include

  • Urine culture and treatment of infection if required
  • Ultrasound of the kidney, ureter, and bladder
  • Intravenous pyelography
  • Methylene blue - 3 swab test if the fistula is small. Here, methylene blue is injected into the bladder via the catheter, and three sterile swabs are placed into the vaginal cavity.  
    • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in the ureterovaginal fistula
    • The middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, as seen in the vesicovaginal fistula
    • The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in the urethrovaginal fistula
  • Cystourethroscopy helps in fistula localisation, determination of its proximity to the ureteral orifices, inspection for multiple fistula sites, etc.

Vesicovaginal fistula is treated surgically. It can be attempted after 3 months to allow the inflammation to subside and clear the infection. After this, the Latzko procedure can be performed. Here, the vaginal epithelium around the fistula is removed, and the edges are approximated. The Chassar Moir technique can also be attempted. Here, the vagina and bladder are separated and sutured into two layers taking care to avoid tension and overlapping suture lines. 

Vesicouterine fistula (Option C) is very rare and generally occurs after operative surgeries on the uterus. The patient will have cyclical hematuria as the menstrual blood and urine mix. 

Ureterovaginal fistulae (Option D) result from direct injury to the ureter during gynecologic surgery (Eg, Wertheim's procedure for Ca cervix). Urine dribbles from both the vagina and urethra post-surgery. The three-swab test will not stain with methylene blue but with urine.

Related Pearl: Difference between bladder fistula & ureteric fistula

  Bladder fistula   Ureteric fistula 
Etiology

Obstetric causes:

  • Prolonged obstructed labor
  • Instrumental deliveries
  • Iatrogenic injury during caesarean section or sling operations

Surgical injury during:

  • Abdominal hysterectomy
  • Vaginal hysterectomy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic surgeries
  • Caesarean section
Clinical features

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is unable to micturate

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is able to micturate
Methylene blue 3-swab test Middle swab stains with methylene blue   Uppermost swab stains with urine, but not with methylene blue
Intravenous pyelography Normal Hydronephrosis and hydroureter present on the affected side

 

Related Pearl: Methylene blue - 3 swab test

In the methylene blue 3-swab test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus. A diluted solution of methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a transurethral catheter. After 15 to 30 minutes, the swabs are removed serially and inspected for dye.

Interpretation:

  • Upper swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter: Ureterovaginal fistula
  • Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder: Vesicovaginal fistula
  • Lower swab gets stained - the leak is from the urethra: Urethrovaginal fistula

The given image shows the 3-swab test.

questions.text: A 56-year-old multipara woman presented with grade II/III uterine prolapse with cystocele. She complains of passing urine on, coughing and sneezing. What is the grade as per the genuine stress incontinence scale?
questions.solution:
A patient with prolapse and cystocele experiencing urination on coughing and sneezing has stress incontinence of grade I. 

In stress incontinence, there is an involuntary leakage of urine whenever there is increased intraabdominal pressure (e.g., sneezing, coughing, Valsalva manoeuvre). It is because of a lack of detrusor muscle contraction.

Risk factors include:

  • Age and menopause - due to estrogen deficiency
  • Multiparity - due to loss of pelvic muscle tone
  • Obesity
  • Smoking
  • Constipation
  • Chronic cough
  • Pelvic organ prolapse
  • Pregnancy - due to the effect of progesterone and pressure of the gravid uterus on the bladder neck.
  • Puerperium - due to descent of the bladder neck, loss of urethro-vesical angle, and reduced pelvic muscle tone 
  • Surgical repair of vesicovaginal fistula

Grading of genuine stress incontinence (GSI) :

  • Grade I: Incontinence with only severe stress - coughing, sneezing, and jogging.
  • Grade II: Incontinence with moderate stress - walking and going up and down the stairs.
  • Grade III: Incontinence with mild stress - standing.

Investigations include the stress test, cotton swab or Q tip test, Marshall and Bonney’s test, urethroscopy, and urodynamic studies. These are required before surgery and not required before conservative management.

Conservative management includes Kegel's pelvic exercises, electric nerve stimulation, devices like pessaries, vaginal cones, and artificial sphincters. Medical treatment with estrogen creams, alpha agonists, venlafaxine, and imipramine may be useful.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented with complaints of irregular periods, acne, and increased facial hair growth. USG revealed multiple ovarian follicles arranged in a necklace pattern. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Fall in sex hormone binding globulin

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a history of irregular periods, acne, increased facial hair growth, and USG showing multiple ovarian follicles arranged in a necklace pattern is suggestive of polycystic ovarian disease(PCOD), and in PCOD, Estrone>Estradiol(E1>E2).

Insulin induces LH to cause theca-cell hyperplasia and secrete androgens, testosterone, and epiandrostenedione, which are converted to estrogen in the granulosa cells. Epi-androstenedione is converted in the peripheral fat to oestrone. This leads to a rise in estrogen and inhibin levels. These, in turn, cause a high LH surge resulting in a low FSH/LH ratio (Option D). While the oestrone level increases, the oestradiol level remains normal, which raises the Oestrone: Oestradiol ratio(E1>E2). Sex hormone binding globulin (SHBG) level is also reduced. (Option A)

Polycystic ovarian syndrome 

Important clinical features of PCOS are menstrual abnormalities (70%) - oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea, obesity, hirsutism, acne, and alopecia due to hyperandrogenism (testosterone>1.5ng/mL) (Option C), acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance, and infertility.

Rotterdam criterion is used to diagnose PCOS.  Any two of the three components of this criteria establish the diagnosis of PCOS.

  • Oligo/ amenorrhoea, anovulation, infertility
  • Hirsutism/ acne
  • Ultrasound findings- Enlarged ovaries with ovarian volume of more than 10 mm3 with 12 or more small follicles, each 2-9 mm in size, placed peripherally.

The ultrasound image below shows an enlarged ovary with multiple follicles in the periphery.

Management of PCOD is individualized. Weight reduction and lifestyle changes are the first-line therapy for PCOD. Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation pills with 30 mcg E2 and 2-3 mg drospirenone, are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. Hirsutism and acne are managed with OCP with cyproterone acetate and topical agents such as eflornithine, clindamycin lotion 1%, erythromycin gel 2%, and isotretinoin. 

Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance, which can be controlled with metformin and acarbose. Patients presenting with infertility are treated by inducing ovulation using clomiphene as a first-line drug, along with dexamethasone and letrozole.

Surgical management includes laparoscopic ovarian drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary.

Note:

PCOS in association with diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia and cardiovascular disease presenting in reproductive age group is known as "X syndrome".

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: Your senior resident asks you to evaluate patients for hormone replacement therapy(HRT) admitted to the gynaecology ward. You would consider prescribing HRT to which of the following patients?

choices.text: A 50 year old woman with osteoporosis and history of atherosclerosis
A 52 year old woman with hot flushes and history of breast cancer
A 55 year old woman with atrophic vagina and history of DVT
A 48 year old woman with hot flushes and deranged liver function tests

questions.solution:
Among the given options, a 50-year-old woman with osteoporosis and a history of atherosclerosis is the only one who could be considered for starting HRT (Hormone replacement therapy).

Indications for HRT:

  • Therapeutic: Symptomatic women who suffer from estrogen deficiency gonadal dysgenesis in adolescents.
  • Prophylactic: High-risk cases for menopausal complications such as cardiovascular disease (atherosclerosis), osteoporosis, Alzheimer’s disease, colonic cancer, Premature menopause following hysterectomy, tubectomy, radiotherapy, chemotherapy.

Contraindications for HRT:

  • Breast cancer (option B), uterine cancer, or family history of cancer
  • Previous history of the thromboembolic episode (option C)
  • Liver and gallbladder diseases (option D)
  • Uterine fibroids—the fibroids may enlarge in size

Risks of HRT:

  • Endometrial cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Ovarian cancer
  • Thromboembolism
  • Lipid profile dysfunction
  • Gallstones, liver dysfunction

A minimum of 12 days (in a month) of progesterone added to ERT reduces the risk of endometrial cancer to 2%

Newer research and their observations reveal that a few women need prophylactic and therapeutic HRT, but 70–85% of women remain healthy and need only good nutrition and a healthy lifestyle.

questions.text:
A couple presented to the infertility clinic as they had been unable to conceive. The lady is 25 years old and has normal reports, however, her 27-year-old husband presents with a semen analysis report that is as follows. What is the next best step in the management of this condition?
  • Appearance: Opalescent
  • Volume: 2ml
  • pH: 7.5
  • Sperm count: absent
questions.solution:
As the semen analysis of the patient indicates an absence of sperm in the semen, the next step is to repeat the semen analysis after a month.

During this time, the patient should be advised to take a good nutritional diet and restrict smoking and consumption of alcohol. He should take a cold or tepid bath and discard tight underwear. Only after two negative or below-average counts, he can be diagnosed as azoospermic or oligospermic.

Azoospermia is characterized by the total absence of sperm in semen. This may result from male reproductive tract obstruction or from nonobstructive causes. Obstructive azoospermia may result from a prior vasectomy or ejaculatory duct obstruction. However, congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens (CBAVD) can cause of azoospermia.

Nonobstructive azoospermia may be caused by a karyotypic abnormality such as Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY) or balanced translocation; deletion of a small portion of the Y chromosome; testicular failure; or unexplained causes. Serum FSH is used to differentiate between obstructive and nonobstructive azoospermia(option A). It is elevated in a case of nonobstructive azoospermia. Chromosomal studies are done in cases of nonobstructive azoospermia (option D).

Management of Azoospermia

Obstructive azoospermia requires a vasogram to study the site and nature of the blockage. Vaso-vassal anastomosis has been successful in a few cases. The advantage of surgery over ICSI is that it is a one-time treatment and cost-effective, if successful with permanent effect. In a case of non-obstructive azoospermia, especially in hormonal deficiencies, GnRH and pituitary hormones have been used to induce spermatogenesis.

Other methods of treatment for male infertility are as follows:

• IVF
• Gamete intra-fallopian transfer (GIFT) technique
• Microassisted fertilization (MAF) technique
• Microsurgical epididymal sperm aspiration (MESA) or percutaneous epididymal sperm aspiration (PESA).

Related Pearl: Semen Analysis : WHO Criteria (2022)

Criteria, Normal values, Lowest reference limits (in brackets)

Semen analysis Normal reference value and minimal reference (in parenthesis) limit
Volume 2ml or more (1.4ml)
pH 7.2-7.8
Viscosity Less than 3
Sperm concentration 20 million/ml (15 million/ml)
Total sperm count More than 40 million/ejaculate
Motility More than 50% progressive forward motility(Progressive motility = 30%)
Morphology More than 4% normal form (lower reference limit)
Forward progression >2 (Scale of 0-4)
Viability 54% or more living
Leucocytes Less than 1 million/ml
Round cells Less than 5 million/ml
Sperm agglutination Less than 10 spermatozoa with adherent particles (<2)

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for intra-cytoplasmic sperm injection?
questions.solution:
Tubal block is not an indication for intra-cytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI), which involves injecting a single chosen sperm into the cytoplasm of the oocyte.

Related Pearl: Indications for various procedures in Infertility treatment

Indications of artificial insemination with husband's semen:

  • Chronic medical disorder
  • Oligospermia after sperm washout
  • Impotency or ejaculatory failure
  • Premature ejaculation, retrograde ejaculation
  • Hypospadias
  • Antisperm antibodies in the cervical mucus
  • Unexplained infertility
  • Frozen sperm: If the husband needs to undergo radiotherapy or chemotherapy or is not available at the time of ovulation
  • X–Y fractionation of sperms for sex selection, in a genetic and chromosomal abnormality
  • HIV positive male or female

Indications for Intra-cytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) and gamete intra-fallopian transfer (GIFT):

  • Sperm count of less than 5 million/mL
  • Absent or reduced sperm motility
  • Abnormal sperm morphology
  • Previous failed IVF
  • Unexplained infertility
  • Failure to penetrate zona by sperm as seen in IVF

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with a 6-month history of a non-healing genital ulcer. Examination revealed a solitary ulcer measuring 3cm x 2cm on the labia majora. No lymph nodes were palpable. Biopsy revealed nests of malignant squamous epithelium with prominent central keratin pearls surrounded by a chronic inflammatory infiltrate. Which of the following is not considered a risk factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of squamous carcinoma of the vulva, and HPV 11 infection is not considered a risk factor.

Infection with HPV types 16, 18, 31, 33, and 45 are known to be associated with the risk of the development of vulvar carcinoma. HPV 16 infection is the most common. HPV 6 and 11 cause most cases of genital warts but are seldom linked to cancer and are known as low-risk HPV.

Squamous cell carcinoma is the most frequent vulvar carcinoma, followed by malignant melanoma. Patients present with pruritis and a visible lesion that may be ulcerated, bleeding, warty, raised, or pigmented. There may be other clinical entities, such as preinvasive neoplasia (vulval intraepithelial neoplasia - VIN), infection, chronic inflammatory disease, and granulomatous disease.

On histopathological examination, the tumor shows classic features of invasive squamous cell carcinoma, such as squamous cells, intercellular bridges, and eosinophilic keratin pearls. Nests of invasive tumor cells are surrounded by chronic inflammation.

Risk factors for vulvar carcinoma: 

  • Age: The risk of vulvar cancer increases with age; the highest incidence is seen in women over 70 years of age.
  • Human papillomavirus (HPV)- HPV 16 is the most commonly associated type, but HPV types 18, 31, 33, and 45 are also known risk factors.
  • HSV infection (usually in a smoker)
  • Smoking
  • Chronic immunosuppression - HIV infection, transplantation patients
  • Lichen sclerosus- chronic vulvar inflammatory disease and can be considered a precursor lesion, usually in older women
  • Other genital cancers: Women with cervical cancer might have a higher risk of vulvar cancer  
  • Progression from VIN

The images below show Stages IA, IB, 2, 3, 4A, and 4B of vulvar carcinoma in order:

Related Pearl: Treatment Modality in Vulval Cancer

Stage Treatment
1A
  •  Radical wide local excision
     
1B
  • Partial vulvectomy + ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection
II
  • Tumor 2-4cm – total vulvectomy + B/L groin lymph node dissection
  • Tumor >4cm or poorly differentiated – radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
 
III
  • Megavoltage radiotherapy
  • Local surgical excision - Radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
  • Local recurrence – chemotherapy
 
IV
  • Chemotherapy or radiotherapy
  • Local excision on residual tumor
  • ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node + ve – contralateral node removed
  • Femoral lymph node +ve – pelvic lymph node removed

 

Related Pearl: Staging of Vulval Cancer (FIGO)

Stage Features
I Tumor confined to vulva
IA Lesions ≤2 cm in size, confined to the vulva or perineum and with stromal invasion ≤ 1 mm, no nodal metastasis
IB Lesions >2cm in size or with stromal invasion >1mm , confined to the vulva or perineum, with negative nodes
II Tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with negative nodes
III Tumor of any size with/without extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with positive inguinofemoral lymph nodes
IIIA i) With 1 lymph node macrometastases (≥5mm) or,
  ii)1-2 lymph node micrometastases(<5mm)
IIIB i) With 2 or more lymph node macrometastases (≥5mm), or
  ii) 3 or more lymph node micrometastases (<5 mm)
IIIC With positive nodes with extracapsular spread
IV Tumor invades other regional structures (upper 2/3rd urethra, upper 2/3rd vagina) or distant structures
IVA Tumour invades any of the following:
  i) Upper urethral and/or vaginal mucosa, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa, or fixed to the pelvic bone, or
  ii) Fixed or ulcerated inguinofemoral lymph nodes
IVB Any distant metastasis including pelvic lymph nodes

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with painful menses and pain during intercourse. She has not conceived despite having unprotected intercourse for the past 2 years. Per vaginal examination reveals tenderness in the lateral fornices. On bimanual examination, a normal-sized nulligravid uterus is felt. A speculum examination reveals bluish-puckered spots in the posterior fornix. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient’s painful menses (dysmenorrhea), pain during intercourse (dyspareunia), lateral fornicial tenderness, bluish spots in the posterior fornix, and infertility suggest endometriosis.

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue at a site outside the uterine cavity. It is found in ectopic sites such as the ovary, pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligaments, appendix, pelvic lymph nodes, lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) scar endometriosis, umbilicus, and lung.

Endometriosis can present as blue or red powdered burned lesions on the cervix or posterior vaginal fornix, scarring around the tissue (puckered look). Other features include chocolate cysts causing left/right lower quadrant pain, pain during defecation, chronic pelvic pain and infertility, right lower quadrant pain, and cyclical hemoptysis.

Laparoscopy is the gold standard modality for the diagnosis and treatment of endometriosis. 'Powder-burn' - puckered black spots, red vascular, bluish, blackish cysts, chocolate cysts, and dense adhesions in the pelvis, as well as yellow-brown peritoneal fluid, can be seen on laparoscopy.

For minimal disease medical management with NSAIDs and oral contraceptive pills are given if associated menstrual complaints are present. OCPs inhibit gonadotropin release and decrease the menstrual flow. For moderate to severe diseases oral progestogens, GnRH agonists or danazol that antagonize estrogenic effects on the endometrium causing endometrial atrophy are used.

Surgery is preferred in infertile women because hormonal treatment would delay pregnancy. Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser and resection of endometrioma can be done. Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA) to control pain .Total hysterectomy with bilateral oophorectomy is a definitive and most effective therapy for women with endometriosis who do not wish to retain fertility.

Option A- Chronic pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) closely mimics endometriosis in its symptoms and signs. Both conditions produce pelvic pain, congestive dysmenorrhea, menorrhagia, and sterility. The uterus is retroverted and fixed. But in chronic PID, thickened and slightly tender fornices or a tubo-ovarian mass is noted and speculum finding as seen in the patient described above is not seen in chronic PID.

Option B - Rectocele is a form of genital prolapse seen frequently in menopausal women, especially those with a history of pelvic floor injury or multiparity. Patients present with varying degrees of prolapsed mass per rectum that needs splinting for a satisfactory bowel movement. 

 Option C - Adenomyosis, a condition seen frequently in elderly women (Aged> 40 years), is characterized by endometrial islands in the wall of the uterus, leading to a symmetrically enlarged uterus (not more than 14 weeks size). Usual presenting features include menorrhagia and progressively increasing dysmenorrhea. Per vaginal exam findings are normal.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: An 82-year-old female patient presented with a non-healing ulcer on the labia majora for 1 year which appears to be 3 cm x 4 cm on the surface. Biopsy shows squamous cell carcinoma. Further investigations reveal the tumour has invaded the upper 2/3rd of the urethra with inguinal lymph node involvement of <5mm. What is the stage of vulval cancer in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has a stage IIIA vulval carcinoma, as the tumour has invaded the upper 2/3rd of the urethra with inguinal lymph node involvement of <5mm.

Staging of vulval cancer:

Stage I Tumour confined to the vulva
IA Lesions ≤2 cm in size, and with stromal invasion ≤ 1 mm
IB Lesions >2cm in size or with stromal invasion >1mm

The image below shows Stage II vulval cancer. Tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd of the urethra, lower 1/3rd of the vagina, lower 1/3rd of the anus) with negative nodes.

The image below shows Stage III vulval cancer. Tumour of any size with/without extension to adjacent perineal structures (upper 2/3rd urethra, upper 2/3rd vagina, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa) with any number of positive nonfixed, nonulcerated inguinofemoral lymph nodes.

IIIA Regional lymph node metastasis <5mm
IIIB Regional lymph node metastasis >5mm 
IIIC With positive nodes with extracapsular spread

Stage IV: Tumour of any size fixed to bone, or fixed, ulcerated lymph node metastasis or distant structures.

IVA Disease fixed to pelvic bone or fixed or ulcerated regional lymph node metastasis.
IVB Distant metastasis.

Related Pearl: Treatment Modality in Vulval Cancer

Stage Treatment
1A
  •  Radical wide local excision
     
1B
  • Partial vulvectomy + ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection
II
  • Tumor 2-4cm – total vulvectomy + B/L groin lymph node dissection
  • Tumor >4cm or poorly differentiated – radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
 
III
  • Megavoltage radiotherapy
  • Local surgical excision - Radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
  • Local recurrence – chemotherapy
 
IV
  • Chemotherapy or radiotherapy
  • Local excision on residual tumor
  • ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node + ve – contralateral node removed
  • Femoral lymph node +ve – pelvic lymph node removed

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the clinic to discuss options for contraception. She has two children but is unsure whether she has completed her family. She has been smoking 4-5 cigarettes per day for the past 15 years. Her menses are regular, but with heavy menstrual bleeding. Which of the following will be the most ideal contraceptive method for this patient?
questions.solution:
The best contraceptive method for this patient would be a  Norplant (progesterone) subdermal implant. It is one of the most effective contraceptive methods other than sterilization.

This patient is unsure whether she has completed her family, so she cannot be offered surgical sterilization (Option D). Oral contraceptive pills (Option A) are contraindicated in this patient who is a smoker over 35 years of age. Copper-T intrauterine device (Option C) will worsen this patient's heavy menstrual bleeding; therefore, it is not the best choice for this patient. 

Mechanism of action of implants:

  • Inhibits ovulation in 90% of the cycles for the first one year of use
  • Also causes atrophy of the endometrium and cervical mucus thickening

Insertion:

The capsules are inserted subdermally, in the inner aspect of the nondominant arm, 6–8 cm above the elbow fold between the biceps and triceps muscles. 

The implants are inserted on the first day of the menstrual cycle, within 5 days of abortion, and 3 weeks after the delivery. The woman needs to use barrier contraception or abstain in the first 7 days of insertion.

Advantages of implants:

  • They are long-acting with sustained effect—compliance is good.
  • They are coitus-independent with no ‘nuisance’ of daily oral or frequent injections.
  • Pregnancy rate varies between 0.2 and 1.3 per 100 woman years.

Disadvantages of implants:

  • Breakthrough bleeding, irregular cycles, and amenorrhea occur as with other progestogenic contraceptives.
  • Ectopic pregnancy is reported in 1.3% of users.
  • Local infection may occur.
  • The implant requires insertion and removal with nonbiodegradable capsules, which are, however, minor surgical procedures.
  • The implants are expensive and cost rupees 10,000.

Norplant I  contains six silastic capsules- has been withdrawn and replaced by a single rod implant.

Norplant II (Jadelle) consists of two rods each containing 70 mg LNG. The daily release of hormone is 50 mcg, and it provides contraception for 3–5 years.

Implanon: Amenorrhea is common at the end of 1 year. Acne is reduced, and there is no risk of osteoporosis.

Related Pearl: Classification Of Contraceptives Based On Effectiveness

Category Failure rate in first year Contraceptive
First tier  < 2 % IUCD, Implants, Sterilization
Second tier  3-9 % Hormonal - oral, injected, transdermal patches, transvaginal rings
Third tier  10-20 % Barrier, Fertility awareness method
Fourth tier  21-30 % Spermicidal preparations

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: A Pap smear from a patient is shown below. Identify the characteristics of the cell seen.
questions.solution:
The cell shown above from a pap smear is an intermediate squamous cell, which is progesterone-dominant. Cells seen in pap smear are:

Type of cell Identification features
Basal & Parabasal cells

Cells are small, rounded, basophilic, with large nuclei. 

Predominantly seen in smears from post-menopausal women
 Intermediate cells

Cells are squamous cells, transparent and basophilic (blue/green) with vesicular nuclei.

Progesterone-dominant
Superficial cells 

Cells are acidophilic (pink), with pyknotic nuclei

Estrogen-dominant
Malignant cells Hyperchromatic nuclei, granular chromatin and scanty cytoplasm in undifferentiated malignant cells.
Human papillomavirus-infected cells Koilocytes with perinuclear halo and peripheral condensation of cytoplasm

A predominance of superficial or superficial and intermediate cells is seen in women of reproductive age. A predominance of intermediate cells is seen in the luteal phase, in pregnancy, with amenorrhea, and in newborns, premenarchal girls, and women in early menopausal transition. A predominance of parabasal cells is seen in menopausal patients with atrophy.

questions.text: Which female genital cancer is associated with metabolic disturbances like diabetes, obesity, and hypertension?
questions.solution:
Endometrial cancer has been found to be associated with metabolic disturbances like diabetes, obesity, and hypertension, also known as corpus cancer syndrome.

Endometrial carcinoma is the most common invasive cancer of the female genital tract. Type 1 endometrial carcinoma shows endometrioid morphology and is associated with the following:

  • Unopposed estrogen exposure (endometrial hyperplasia)
  • Obesity
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Hypertension

The tumor-suppressor gene PTEN is mutated in approximately 20% of endometrial hyperplasias.

Genomic sequencing of endometrial carcinoma has revealed 4 major molecular subtypes of endometrioid and serous carcinomas:

  • Ultramutated/POLE tumors - mutations in DNA polymerase ε (POLE)
  • Hypermutated/MSI (microsatellite instability) tumors - mutations involving mismatch repair genes
  • Copy number low/MSS (microsatellite stable) tumors - mutations involving the PI3K/AKT pathway
  • Copy number high/serous-like tumors - TP53 mutations and numerous genomic copy number variants

questions.text:
A 35-year old lady came to the gynecology outpatient department with complaints of foul-smelling, frothy vaginal discharge. A fresh sample of the discharge is taken and 10 percent potassium hydroxide is added to it. This releases a strong fishy odor. Which of the following conditions can be the etiology of the discharge?
  1. Candidiasis
  2. Trichomonas vaginalis
  3. Bacterial vaginosis
  4. Chlamydia
  5. Gonorrhea
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 2 and 3.

The test described is the Whiff test, which is positive in Trichomonas vaginalis infections and bacterial vaginosis.

The whiff test is performed by the addition of 10 percent potassium hydroxide (KOH) to a fresh sample of vaginal secretions. In a positive test, it releases volatile amines that have a fishy odor. With bacterial vaginosis, the vaginal pH is > 4.5, as a result of diminished acid production by bacteria. Trichomonas vaginalis infection is also associated with anaerobic overgrowth and the production of amines. Thus, women diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis should have no microscopic evidence of trichomoniasis.

Bacterial vaginosis is caused by an alteration in the normal vaginal flora, where a decrease in the number of lactobacilli leads to an increase in the number of other organisms like Hemophilus vaginalis, Gardnerella, Mobiluncus, and Mycoplasma hominis. It is diagnosed using Amsel's criteria, where at least three of the four following criteria should be present to confirm the diagnosis:

  • Homogenous vaginal discharge
  • Vaginal pH > 4.5
  • Amine like odor on adding KOH (Whiff test positive)
  • Clue cells (>20% of cells)

The presence of both clue cells and a positive Whiff test result is pathognomonic of bacterial vaginosis, even if asymptomatic. It is treated with 500 mg of metronidazole twice daily for 7 days.

Trichomonas vaginalis is an infection of the female genital tract with the Trichomonas vaginalis protozoan. It characteristically causes a copious, frothy, offensive yellow-green discharge with vaginal soreness or irritation and urinary frequency. On examination, the vagina looks red and inflamed. The inflamed cervix looks like a strawberry with punctate hemorrhagic spots.

It is treated with metronidazole 2 g orally in a single dose (Standard treatment) or tinidazole 2 g orally in a single dose.

questions.text: A young nulligravid woman is prepared to undergo a hysterosalpingogram to look for uterine anomalies. Which of the following instruments are used during the procedure?
questions.solution:
Rubins cannula (Instrument 1) and Leech Wilkinson cannula (Instrument 2) are used in injecting dye while performing hysterosalpingogram.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a technique used for visualisation of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes by the injection of a radiopaque dye and visualisation of the dye by fluoroscopy as it passes through the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes.

It is best performed between the end of the menstrual period and ovulation (i.e. 9th or 10th day of the cycle).

The patient is pre-medicated with atropine and analgesia to prevent tubal spasms, especially in an apprehensive woman. Then, 10-15ml of the dye is injected using a Leech-Wilkinson cannula, Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter. If the tubes are patent, the dye will spill out of the tubal ostia and smear the adjacent bowel.

It is used to detect:

  • Tubal block.
  • Uterine anomalies
  • Uterine polyps
  • Uterine synechiae
  • The feasibility of tuboplasty by studying the location and extent of tubal pathology

Contraindications for HSG:

  • Presence of genital tract infection and bleeding.
  • Genital tuberculosis due to the risk of spreading infection.
  • Suspected pregnancy.
  • Allergy to the dye.
  • Premenstrual phase
    • If, by chance, pregnancy has occurred, it may be dislodged.
    • Thick endometrium might prevent the smooth flow of the dye at the cornual end.
    • There is a risk of embolism and endometriosis if HSG is done during this phase.

Other options:

Instrument 3 - Karman's cannula. It is used for menstrual regulation. It can be identified by the whistle-like tip.

Instrument 4 - Simpson's uterine sound. It is used to measure the length of uterus. It can be identified by the markings used for measurement.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: A 20-year old female patient presented with painless lesions on the vulva as shown in the image below. Which of the following vaccines is not protective against this condition?
questions.solution:
The condition in the image is condyloma acuminata (venereal warts) caused by infection with human papilloma virus 6 or 11. The Cervarix vaccine does not protect against it. Cervarix offers protection against HPV subtypes 16,18, which cause CIN and Ca cervix.

The image shows multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal, as seen in condyloma acuminata. The verrucous growths may appear discrete or coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths. They may be asymptomatic but can also cause discomfort, discharge, or bleeding. Treatment may include ablation, excision, or topical agents such as podophyllin and imiquimod.

The available vaccinations against HPV are summarized below.

Brand name Cervarix Gardasil Gardasil-9
Characteristic and HPV subtypes Bivalent:16,18 Quadrivalent: 6,11,16,18 Nonavalent: 6,11,16,18,31,33,45,52,58
Protects against: CIN, Ca cervix Anogenital warts, CIN, Ca cervix Anogenital warts, CIN, CA cervix,  Vulval intraepithelial neoplasia, Vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia
Dose 0.5ml  0.5ml 0.5ml
Administration 0, 1, 6 months i.m 0, 2, 6 months i.m 0, 2, 6months, i.m
Administered gender Female and male Female and male Female and male
Ideal Age range: 11-12 years,9-26 years  11-12 years, 9-26 years for both male and female

Females:11-12 years, 9-26 years

Males:11-12 years

9-15 years - FDA approved

Gardasil 9 has received expanded indication, which now includes the prevention of oropharyngeal and other head and neck cancers caused by HPV types 16,18,31,33,45,52,58.

questions.text: A young woman with a history of prior Chlamydia infection presents with low-grade fever and lower abdominal pain. She has cervical motion tenderness and a mucopurulent vaginal discharge on pelvic examination. What is the treatment of choice in this condition?

choices.text: Injection ceftriaxone  + oral doxycycline + oral metronidazole

questions.solution:
The best treatment is a single IM injection of ceftriaxone with oral doxycycline and oral metronidazole for 14 days for pelvic inflammatory disease most likely due to Chlamydia trachomatis. 

Criteria to diagnose PID: Any one of the minimum criteria + 1 or more additional criteria are required for the clinical diagnosis of PID.

Minimum criteria

  • Lower abdominal tenderness
  • Adnexal tenderness
  • Cervical motion tenderness.

Additional criteria

  • Oral temperature >38.3oC
  • Mucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge and cervical friability
  • Presence of abundant WBC on saline microscopy of vaginal fluid
  • Raised ESR or CRP
  • Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with N. gonorrhoeae or C. trachomatis.

The definitive diagnosis of PID is through histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsy. Imaging (TVS/MRI) showing evidence of thickened fluid-filled tubes indicating tubo-ovarian abscess. Laparoscopic evidence of PID is confirmative.

Outpatient management of PID: Inj. ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose + doxycycline 100 mg BD x 14 days + metronidazole 500 mg BD x 14 days.

Indications for hospitalization in PID 

  • Surgical emergencies like appendicitis, generalized peritonitis, etc. 
  • Tubo-ovarian abscess
  • Pregnancy
  • oral temperature >38.5°C, severe nausea and vomiting
  • Unable to follow or tolerate an outpatient oral regimen
  • No clinical response to oral antimicrobial therapy

Parenteral treatment for PID in hospitalized patients: 

  • Inj. cefotetan + oral doxycycline 
  • (or) Inj. cefoxitin + oral doxycycline
  • (or) Inj.clindamycin + inj. gentamicin 

After clinical improvement of the patient with parenteral therapy, transition to oral therapy with doxycycline and metronidazole is recommended to complete 14 days of antimicrobial therapy.

To minimize disease transmission, women should be instructed to abstain from sexual intercourse until therapy is completed, symptoms have resolved, and partners have been adequately treated.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old P1L1 woman comes 8 weeks after her delivery for the insertion of an intrauterine device (IUDs). While counseling her, you advise her on the various options and for the duration that they are effective. Match the devices shown below to their period of effectiveness.

a. 7 years 

b. 5 years 

c. 10 years 

d. 3 years
questions.solution:
The correctly matched set is 1- a, 2- c, 3- b, 4- d (option A).

IUDs Duration (years) Remarks
Levonorgestrel intrauterine system (Image 1) 7 The polydimethylsiloxane membrane around the stem acts as a steroid reservoir containing 52 mg of levonorgestrel released at 20 μg/day.
Copper T 380A (Image 2) 10 Contains copper wire with a total surface area of 380 mm2 wound around the vertical stem and each arm.
Multiload 375 (Image 3) 5 375 mm2 of copper wire wound on the vertical stem.
Copper T 200 (Image 4) 3 200-250 mm2 of copper wire wound on the vertical stem.

 Mechanism of action of intrauterine devices:

  • Biochemical and histological changes in the endometrium - Non-specific inflammation causing a gametotoxic, spermicidal effect; macrophage-induced phagocytosis of the spermatozoa is also responsible for contraceptive effect.
  • Increased tubal motility- prevention of fertilization 
  • Endometrial inflammation decreases sperm motility and inhibits fertilization 
  • Copper-containing devices cause enzymatic interference preventing implantation by producing cytokines.
  • Hormone-releasing devices induce strong and uniform endometrial suppression and decrease cervical mucus. It may also cause anovulation and a luteal-phase insufficiency adding to its contraceptive effect.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida complains of severe abdominal pain. On examination, she is exhausted and dehydrated. Obstructed labour is suspected, and a cesarean section was performed. During cesarean, a uterine anomaly was visualised, as shown in the image below. Which uterine anomaly corresponds to your finding during the cesarean section?
questions.solution:
The anomaly seen intraoperatively is suggestive of a bicornuate uterus. It is important to note that a septate uterus has a smooth fundal contour, whereas a bicornuate uterus has an indented fundus.

A bicornuate uterus is characterized by two separate endometrial cavities that may communicate with each other and a single uterine cervix. The incomplete fusion of the müllerian ducts causes it. Failure of fusion may extend to the cervix, resulting in a complete bicornuate uterus, or may be partial, causing a milder abnormality. 

On hysterosalpingography (HSG), the bicornuate uterus is seen as widely diverging horns with an intercornual angle > 105 degrees. Also, DC Dutta 8th Ed mentions 75 - 105 degrees as a grey area in diagnosing bicornuate or septate uterus. However, MR imaging is necessary to define the external or fundal contour.

A septate uterus is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity due to the failure of the medial segments of the Müllerian ducts to regress. This creates a permanent septum within the uterine cavity. The septum can project partially from the fundus or can extend completely to the cervical os. On HSG, the septate uterus is seen as widely diverging horns with an intercornual angle <75 degrees. 

HSG provides information about the interior of the uterine cavity and not the exterior. Therefore, it cannot differentiate between a septate uterus and a bicornuate uterus. Transvaginal 3-D ultrasonography (3D TV USG) helps to differentiate between the bicornuate uterus and a septate uterus and is recommended for the assessment of patients with a suspected uterine anomaly. MRI is an accurate investigation to diagnose the septate uterus. Hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy can confirm both the internal and the external contour of the uterus. 

Other options:

Option B: The transverse vaginal septum most commonly occurs due to failure of canalization of the vaginal plate or fusion of Mullerian ducts. Patients with an obstructive or imperforate vaginal septum present with symptoms similar to the imperforate hymen. 

Option C: Septate uterus would have a smooth contour due to remnant septum within the endometrial cavity, unlike in this image, which has two distinguishable horns.

Option D: Unicornuate uterus is the formation of the uterus and fallopian tube that occurs entirely from one Mullerian duct due to developmental arrest of the other Mullerian duct.

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications

  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia

  • Abortions

  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery

  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: An actress wants to undergo a permanent method of sterilization. However, she is concerned about the resulting scars on her abdomen. Which of the following methods of sterilization would best suit her case?
questions.solution:
Essure would best suit the actress as it is done through the hysteroscopic method, thus, avoiding abdominal scar.

The Essure permanent device is the latest method of hysteroscopic sterilization. It is a dynamically expanding micro-inserter consisting of a flexible inner coil made of stainless steel and a dynamic outer coil made of nickel-titanium alloy (nitinol). In the inner coil, there is a layer of polyethylene terephthalate fibers that occludes the fallopian tube by initiating a benign local fibrous tissue growth. This is an irreversible and permanent technique. Tubal blockage can be confirmed 3 months later by hysterosalpingography. Its advantages are that there is no abdominal scar and that it can be done under local anesthesia.

However, disadvantages include:

  • Hysteroscopy is required to insert the Essure device
  • Cost and expertise required
  • Permanent method
  • HSG to confirm blockage after 3 months
  • Bilateral insertion is difficult due to spasms in 15% of cases
  • Tuboplasty for reversal is not possible
  • Perforation of the tube 
  • The failure rate is 3.5%

Other options

Option A: Irving procedure involves ligating and excising the mid-portion of the tube after which the proximal stump is buried into the myometrium and the distal stump is buried in the broad ligament. It is an irreversible technique and may require a laparotomy incision.

The procedure described in the image below is the Irving procedure.

Option B:  In Madlener's procedure a loop of the tube is crushed and ligated with a non-absorbable suture.

Option D: In the Pomeroy procedure the fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision, and the middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut and excised as shown in the image below.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with infertility underwent semen analysis. Results show a sperm concentration of 18 million/ml, pH- 7.5, and volume- 2 ml. No agglutination is seen. Morphology shows 10% normal forms and 20% motile sperms. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given semen analysis point towards a diagnosis of asthenospermia as only 20% of the sperms are motile. Normally, 32% of sperm should be motile.

Other options:

Option A: Azoospermia - Absence of sperm in semen

Option C: Normospermia - Sperm concentration of > 15 million/ml

Option D: Oligospermia- Sperm concentration of < 15 million/ml 

Note: 

Morphology is the most important factor/marker of semen analysis.

questions.text: A 21-year-old girl who presented with multiple beefy-red painless ulcers over the vulval region is diagnosed with granuloma inguinale. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The causative organism of granuloma inguinale is Klebsiella granulomatis, a gram-negative bacillus.

Granuloma inguinale begins as a painless nodule that later ulcerates to form multiple beefy red painless ulcers. These ulcers tend to coalesce. There will be minimal adenopathy and progressive destruction of the vulva.

Microscopic examination of smears from the lesion/biopsy specimens reveals pathognomonic intracytoplasmic Donovan bodies and clusters of bacteria with a bipolar (safety-pin) appearance.

The microscopic image below shows the pathognomonic intracytoplasmic Donovan bodies. It also shows clusters of gram-negative bacteria with a bipolar/safety-pin appearance.

Management:

Treatment recommended by the CDC (2015) is azithromycin 1 g once weekly for at least 3 weeks until lesions are completely healed. Alternative regimens include doxycycline, ciprofloxacin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, or erythromycin base.

Other options:

Option A - Chlamydia trachomatis causes lymphogranuloma venereum.

Option C - Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid.

Option D - Herpes simplex virus causes genital herpes.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding candidal vaginitis?
  1. Pregnancy is a risk factor.
  2. Curdy white discharge.
  3. Vaginal pH is >5.5
  4. Fishy odor on a Whiff test.
  5. No need to treat asymptomatic partner.
questions.solution:
The true statements regarding candidal vaginitis are:

  • Pregnancy is a risk factor.
  • Curdy white discharge.
  • No need to treat asymptomatic partner. (It is not transmitted by sexual contact)

The vaginal pH in the case of candidiasis is <4.5 and the Whiff test is negative in the case of candidal vaginitis.

questions.text: During the delivery of a lady with polyhydramnios, an intern pulls the umbilical cord before the separation of the placenta, leading to profuse bleeding. Examination reveals an intact placenta with the uterus partly outside the introitus. Initial resuscitative measures are taken for shock. Which of the following findings does not correlate with the diagnosis?

choices.text: The fundus is inverted into the uterine cavity.
The uterine fundus protrudes through the cervix and lies in the vagina.
The fundus is inverted into the uterine cavity and the cervical os lies at the introitus.
The whole uterus is inverted and protrudes through the introitus.

questions.solution:
The fundus inverted into the uterine cavity, and the cervical os lying at the introitus is a feature of uterine prolapse and does not correlate with the diagnosis of uterine inversion in this patient.

Uterine prolapse is associated with the descent of the cervix into the vagina, to the level of introitus, or outside the vaginal orifice. In an inversion, the uterus is turned inside out without any descent of the cervix.

The given clinical scenario of hemorrhagic shock after attempts of removal of the placenta before placental separation is suggestive of uterine inversion. It is a hemorrhagic complication encountered in the puerperium. Polyhydramnios in this patient contribute to overdistension of the uterus and uterine atony.

Risk factors for uterine inversion:

  • Fundal attachment of the placenta
  • Uterine atony
  • Attempts at cord traction before placental delivery
  • Adherent placenta

There are 3 degrees of uterine inversion:

  • First-degree - the fundus of the uterus inverts into the uterine cavity
  • Second-degree - the uterine fundus protrudes through the cervix and lies in the vagina
  • Third-degree - the whole of the uterus is inverted and protrudes through the introitus

Since uterine inversion presents with profuse bleeding and a severe degree of shock, it requires prompt diagnosis and management. It is managed by promptly repositioning the uterus by exerting a firm and constant pressure on the inverted uterine fundus. The placenta should not be removed until after the replacement of the uterus if it is still attached to the uterus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady undergoes a screening test for cervical cancer. Which of the following is correct with respect to the usage of the given instrument?

choices.text: Five rotations in the same direction

questions.solution:
The given image shows a broom that is used to sample both endo- and ectocervix. Five rotations in the same direction are recommended. 

Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. Cervical cancer screening should start at age 21. Women aged 21-29 should have a Pap smear every 3 years, while women aged 30-65 should have both HPV and Pap co-test every 5 years.

Before the Pap test:

  • The Pap test should not be deferred due to unexplained discharge or unscheduled bleeding as they may be signs of cervical or other genital tract cancers.
  • Ideally scheduled to avoid menstruation. It is best performed around the time of ovulation.
  • Patients should abstain from vaginal intercourse, douching, tampon use, and intravaginal medications for a minimum of 24 to 48 hours prior to the test.
  • Avoid touching the cervix before performing the Pap test, as dysplastic epithelium may get removed.
  • Ideally, confirmed cervicitis or vaginitis should be treated prior to the test

Procedure:

  • The patient is put in a dorsal position, and Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced.
  • The squamocolumnar junction is scraped with Ayre’s spatula, completing at least one full rotation (Option A). It predominantly samples the ectocervix. 
  • The endocervix is scraped with a cytobrush, which is rotated only one-quarter to one-half turn after the ectocervix has been sampled (Option B).
  • A broom simultaneously samples both endo- and ectocervix. Five rotations in the same direction are recommended since reversing direction may cause loss of cellular material. (Option D)
  • Samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides and fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol.
  • Stained with Pap stain or Short stain.

The image below shows the instruments used in cervical sampling: The broom, spatula, and cytobrush in order.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used to treat vasomotor symptoms in menopausal transition?
questions.solution:
Raloxifene is not used to treat vasomotor symptoms in menopause.

Raloxifene (SERM) is used to prevent and treat osteoporosis and to reduce the risk of invasive breast cancer in post-menopausal women. It activates estrogen receptors in the bone but not the breast or uterus. Hot flashes are side effects of Raloxifene therapy (incidence is low).

The menopausal transition is a progressive decline in hormone levels that takes a reproductive-aged woman from regular, cyclic menses to her final menstrual period, ovarian senescence, and beyond. Menopausal transition begins with irregularity in menstrual cycles and extends up until a year after permanent cessation of menses. The average age of onset of menopause is 47 years and ranges between 42 - 58 years.

Symptoms associated with menopausal transition:

Menstrual pattern Shorter cycles (typical), Longer cycles (possible), Irregular bleeding
Vasomotor Hot flashes, Night sweats, Sleep disturbances 
Psychological/cognitive Worsening PMS, Depression, Irritability
Mood swings, Poor concentration and memory
Sexual dysfunction Vaginal dryness, Decreased libido, Dyspareunia
Somatic Headache, Dizziness, Palpitations, Joint aches and back pain
Others Urinary incontinence, Dry and itchy skin, Weight gain 

 

Vasomotor symptoms of menopausal transition:

A sudden wave of heat spreads over the body, particularly the upper body and face. Peripheral vasodilation causes skin temperatures to rise during a hot flash, lasting 1-5 minutes. Elevations in blood pressure, heart rate, metabolic rate and peak blood flow are seen with hot flashes. Anxiety, irritability, panic, and palpitations can also accompany hot flashes. Normal skin temperature is eventually restored.

Hormonal medications routinely administered for treatment of vasomotor symptoms of menopause:

  • Estrogen- CEE, 17B Estradiol, Estradiol acetate ( oral, transdermal patch, vaginal)
  • Progesterone- Medroxyprogesterone acetate, Micronised progesterone.
  • Bazedioxifene(SERM)- Bazedioxifene alone will increase the episodes of hot flashes. However, the combination of CEE and Bazedioxifene called TSEC(Tissue selective estrogen complex) decreases the episodes of hot flashes.

questions.text: A woman presents with a history of recurrent abortions. A hysterosalpingogram is done and shown below. The intercornual angle mentioned in the report is 70 degrees, and the cleft depth is reported to be <1cm.  Ultrasound reveals an intercornual distance of less than 4 cm. What is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a history of recurrent abortion with the given hysterosalpingogram and intercornual angle of 70 degrees, a cleft depth of less than 1cm, and intercornual distance of less than 4 cm suggests a diagnosis of a septate uterus, for which transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum is the appropriate method of treatment.

The procedure involves the resection of the septum under hysteroscopic guidance. Hence, it doesn't scar the uterus and avoids the necessity of cesarean sections for future pregnancies, improving the outcomes.

The following table differentiates the septate and bicornuate uterus:

Study and parameter Septate Bicornuate
Hysterosalpingography(HSG) - cornua position Horns do not diverge Widely diverging horn
Intercornual angle - coronal plane (MRI/3D USG) <75 degrees >105 degrees
Intercornual distance <4 cm >4 cm
Fundal contour Convex, flat or minimally indented Fundal cleft >1 cm from the intercornual line
Intervening myometrium Thin (fibrous) Thick

Other options:

Jones' metroplasty, Strassmann's metroplasty, and Tompkins's metroplasty are surgeries that involve a transabdominal approach, which causes uterine scarring and is hence not preferred. Strassmann's metroplasty is a unification procedure for the bicornuate uterus.

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct
  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.
